sentence: Finally, a total of 42 726 patients were included in our study; a detailed flowchart of case selection is present in Figure 1.

OS, the time from brain cancer diagnosis to death due to any cause, and brain cancer‐specific survival (BCSS), the time from brain cancer diagnosis to death due to brain cancer, were calculated using vital status and cause‐specific death classification, respectively (Figure 2).
Cumulative incidence and Kaplan–Meier curves were generated to illustrate the survival outcomes of brain cancer patients with and without PCH (Figure 3).
The cumulative incidence of death was notably higher in patients with PCH compared to those without (Figure 3A).
However, due to PSM, the cumulative incidences of the two groups became similar (p value = 0.2) (Figure 3B).
PCH had a detrimental impact on the survival of patients (p value <.001) (Figure 3C).
Nevertheless, after PSM, the survival curves converged, indicating comparable outcomes (Figure 3D).

Prior cancer types
Prior cancers were most reported from Genitourinary (40.4%), Breast (13.6%), Hematologic and Lymphatic (11.4%), and Gastrointestinal malignancies (11.3%) (Figure 4).
Figure 5 illustrates the overall survival (OS) of patients with brain cancer who had different types of prior malignancies, as determined by an adjusted Kaplan–Meier curves of the matched dataset.
Finally, a total of 42 726 patients were included in our study; a detailed flowchart of case selection is present in Figure 1.
